qas.question: Why is a transistor so useful?

answers.text: it can act as an amplifier

qas.question: What is an additional use of the transistor?

answers.text: turn current on or off in a circuit

qas.question: What determines the amount of current in an electrically controlled switch?
What controls how strong the output signal is?
How large is a transistor in comparison to a terminal?
What does a signal become when the transistor does not work properly?
Where would an electrically controlled switch be located?

context: The essential usefulness of a transistor comes from its ability to use a <b6_0>small<b6_0/> signal applied between one pair of its <b5_0>terminals<b5_0/> to control a much larger signal at another pair of <b8_0>terminals<b8_0/>. This property is called <a0_0>gain<a0_0/>. It can produce a stronger output signal, a voltage or current, which is proportional to a <b7_0>weaker<b7_0/> input signal; that is, <a1_0>it can act as an amplifier<a1_0/>. Alternatively, the transistor can be used to <a2_0>turn current on or off in a circuit<a2_0/> as an electrically controlled switch, where <b4_0>the amount of current<b4_0/> is determined by <a3_0>other circuit elements<a3_0/>.
